awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Prosodic structure: An integrated empirical and modeling investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines how the prosodic structure of language shapes the articulation of spoken utterances. Speaking is a complex, uniquely human ability that relies on precisely coordinated movements of the speech organs (tongue, lips, jaw, soft palate, and larynx) and respiratory system. These movements produce sounds that listeners perceive and that convey not only the 'dictionary' content of the utterance, but also its prosodic content. Prosody organizes phonological forms into successively larger units or phrases, and renders certain syllables, words and phrases more 'prominent' (perceptually or rhythmically important) to the listener. Understanding the processes that shape prosodic structure and how these processes act to transmit this structure through coordination of the speech organs has profound implications for advancing our understanding of language processing and communication disorders, for improving speech technology, and for providing insights regarding the more general relationship between linguistic and cognitive operations.

The central hypothesis examined in this collaborative project is that the control processes governing temporal and tonal structure are intimately linked with one another. This linkage is viewed as emerging from the underlying motor control dynamics that coordinate the motions of the speech organs and guide speech production. In order to investigate this hypothesis, two additional open questions are addressed concerning the nature of the units that exist at different prosodic and prominence levels, and the relationships among syllables, prosodic feet, words and phrases: "What are the structural and articulatory-acoustic properties of prosodic feet?"; and "How can the relationships among the levels be best understood?" These questions are investigated through a series of articulatory studies--using electromagnetic articulography--and acoustic measurements that will examine: 1) how temporal and tonal properties interact at phrasal boundaries, 2) how temporal and tonal properties interact within and across all levels of prominence, and 3) how motor control dynamics shape the details of articulatory-acoustic structure at the foot level. These studies will be complemented by a series of computational simulations, which will serve the dual purpose of testing the project's hypotheses and guiding further developments of the prosodic component of the group's Task-Dynamics model of speech production.

por.por_cntn:
When we speak, we group words into chunks, called phrases, and we emphasize certain words (and syllables within a word) more than others, which is called prominence. Prosody is the component of our cognitive system for language that adjusts the activities of the speech articulators as they form the consonants and vowels of speech and the resulting sound they produce in order to indicate phrasing and prominence. Both grouping and prominence form hierarchies that are fundamental for successful communication between speakers and listeners. During the period of this award, a set of experiments was conducted, examining the communicative, structural, temporal, and tonal (voice pitch) properties of the prosodic phrasing hierarchy (as a function of type of boundaries between phrases), and the prosodic prominence hierarchy (as a function of the type of focus, the contextually determined spotlighting of some particular word). The project was guided by a view of prosody in which prosody emerges through the dynamic interaction of temporal, spatial and tonal events as well as of lexical and phrasal prosodic levels.

Our work has included empirical, theoretical and modeling investigations. We have identified kinematic correlates (spatiotemporal properties of articulatory movements) of prominence in languages that are known to have very different types of lexical and phrasal prosodic systems (such as American English, Greek, Korean, and Japanese), investigated how those kinematic properties can contribute to the perception of prominence in American English, and probed the interaction of boundaries and prominence in Korean and Japanese. The findings from these studies provide additional evidence for and further development of a theoretical model of prosodic structure in which temporal and spatial properties of speech articulation are essential and in which boundaries and prominence interact in language-specific ways.  We have also found that individual speakers within a language (American English) may differ in the precise kinematic and tonal properties they use to mark boundaries, and that in a conversational interaction the participants often converge in these properties???-participants who mark boundaries with more variability before they begin interacting gradually behave more like their partner. We have also investigated the kinematic properties of pauses between phrases in American English (even though pauses are silent, they have been shown by our work and others? to exhibit characteristic articulatory movements), and have identified how these properties are related to the planning of the upcoming utterance, specifically how their occurrence is driven by the speaker?s need for additional planning time for upcoming utterances.

The prosody of African tone languages (languages in which words differ in their tonal patterns as well as their consonants and vowels) presents unique challenges for marking boundaries and prominence, as pitch must simultaneously convey information to distinguish words and to mark phrasal boundaries (as these languages do not appear to use the otherwise common temporal property of lengthening of the final syllable at boundaries). We contributed to the investigation of how some of these languages (e.g., Embosi) meet these challenges by developing a novel dynamical model of how the pitch of word tones exhibits a pattern of slow changes over time in the course of a phrase, producing a parabolic trajectory of fundamental rise then fall.

The interaction of temporal and spatial properties of speech articulation is relevant not only to prosodic structure but also to the organization of consonants and vowels into syllables (syllable structure). Previous approaches to syllable structure have focused on either temporal or spatial articulatory properties. Our work on Georgian has shown that both properties are necessary, and we have also developed a model of syllable structure that takes them both, as well as their acoustic signatures, into account.

Intellectual Merit: The conducted research provides empirical data and theoretical insight regarding how prosodic and lexical goals jointly determine the articulatory and acoustic patterns of speech and the dynamics that underlie these patterns. They underscore the importance of temporal and spatial information in speech and the interaction of different components of prosodic structure while highlighting cross-linguistic differences.

Broader Impact: The findings contribute to a theoretical understanding of prosodic structure that can serve as a foundation for future typological work. Throughout the duration of the award, five graduate and two undergraduate students were funded, providing them with theoretical and experimental research experience in linguistics, speech science, and movement science.
